questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect in a patient with acute retrobulbar neuritis?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause acute retrobulbar neuritis.

Nutritional optic neuropathy is characterized by bilateral, symmetric, cecocentral scotomas and disturbance of color vision. Fundus morphology is usually normal. 

Deficiencies in the following vitamins are primarily responsible for the damage caused to the optic nerve: B1 (thiamine), B6 (pyridoxine), B9 (folic acid), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins are cofactors for many metabolic reactions and their deficiency leads to toxic byproduct accumulation within cells, which inhibits the electron transport chain and depresses mitochondrial function. Depletion of ATP leads to nerve dysfunction and eventual nerve death.

Chronic alcohol abuse is a commonly associated risk factor and a cause of malnourishment.

questions.text: During a community outreach program in a rural area, you come across a girl with a conjunctival lesion as shown in the image. According to the WHO grading, which grade does this child falls under?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Bitot’s spot, which is seen in the X1B stage of vitamin A deficiency.

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will Koplik’s spots and conjunctivitis be seen together?
questions.solution:
Koplik’s spots are seen in measles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with an extremely painful right foot. He stated that he had an alcohol binge the previous night. On examination, the right first metatarsophalangeal joint is red, swollen, and extremely tender to palpation. Which of the following ocular conditions is not associated with his underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute gout. Glaucoma is not a known association of acute gout.

Ocular manifestations seen in acute gout are episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis. Ocular structures have a relatively poor solvent ability, in addition to lower temperatures. Therefore, they are predisposed to tophi deposition. As a result of urate deposits, crystal-induced inflammation of the affected tissue is responsible for causing episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis.

questions.text: You would expect to see oil drop cataract in a patient with ________
questions.solution:
Oil droplet cataract is seen in galactosemia.

Characteristic associations are:

  • Diabetes - Snowflake cataract
  • Wilson’s disease - Sunflower cataract
  • Homocystinuria - Bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with neurological manifestations was referred from the pediatric OPD. Her ocular examination findings is as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Kayser–Fleisher (KF) ring, which is a characteristic finding of Wilson’s disease.

KF ring consists of the deposition of copper in the Descemet membrane of the cornea. The rings are usually golden-brown and are visible only under the slit-lamp. They do not impair vision. They disappear on treatment with anti-copper drugs and reappear with disease progression. They are a characteristic sign of Wilson’s disease but are not pathognomonic. They can also be seen in:

  • Primary biliary cholangitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Cholestasis.

Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson's disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copper in the centre of the lens. It consists of a greenish central opacity with spoke-like radial opacities and is visible only under the slit-lamp. It is also seen in chalcosis (deposition of intraocular copper-containing foreign body).

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions can occur as an ocular manifestation in a patient with dengue?
  1. Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  2. Uveitis
  3. Cataract
  4. Retinal hemorrhage
  5. Pappilitis
questions.solution:
Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue.

Dengue has varied manifestations, in different organ systems, mainly of inflammation and bleeding. Until recently, apart from retro-orbital pain, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection. Potential pathogenic mechanisms include a direct viral effect on the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on the right side of her face as shown below.  The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a young child presenting with unilateral port wine stain in the region of trigeminal nerve supply and leptomeningeal angioma as seen on MRI is indicative of Sturge-Webber syndrome (SWS). Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of SWS.

Sturge weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder(phakomatoses) that is characterized by unilateral capillary malformation at the region of trigeminal supply known as port wine stain or nevus flammeus, ipsilateral diffuse cavernous hemangioma of the choroid and ipsilateral leptomeningeal hemangiomatosis, which causes seizures and mental retardation.

Ocular manifestation of SWS include:

  • Glaucoma - most common ocular manifestation. It develops anywhere between infancy to adulthood. When developed in infancy it presents as buphthalmos.
  • Diffuse choroidal hemangioma
  • Serous retinal detachment
  • Visual field defects- homonymous hemianopia due to the leptomeningeal hemangiomas affecting the optic tract or occipital lobe.
  • Heterochromia of the iris
  • Episcleral and conjunctival lesions

Option A: Uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue of the eyes. It can be associated with a number of systemic conditions such as sarcoidosis, behcet's disease, ankylosing spondylitis, reiter's syndrome,Toxoplasmosis and Posner–Schlossman syndrome (PSS).

Option B: Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited or acquired pigmentatory retinal dystrophy affecting the rods more. The earliest manifestation is worsening of night blindness which gradually progresses to tunnel vision and ultimately loss of central vision. The classic triad of findings in RP comprises bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation and waxy disc pallor.

Systemic Associations of RP include:

  • Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome
  • Cockayne's syndrome
  • Refsum's syndrome
  • Usher's syndrome
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome

The below given image shows the classical triad findings of Retinitis pigmentosa.

Option C:Keratitis is the inflammation of cornea which is characterised by corneal edema, cellular infiltration and ciliary congestion. It can be either infectious or non-infectious in nature which includes allergic keratitis, neurotrophic keratitis, exposure keratitis and peripheral ulcerative keratopathies such as Rosacea keratitis and Mooren's ulcer.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with complaints of diminution of vision in both eyes for the last 6 - 8 months. On examination, bilateral cataracts were seen.  Incidentally, you also note iris pearls. Which of the following conditions should you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Iris pearls are pearly-white nodules seen on the iris in leprosy.

They are asymptomatic, 0.3 to 1.0 mm in diameter, dull yellowish-white in colour, and are seen at an early stage of the disease. It is not associated with any inflammatory changes in the anterior chamber. Histologically, it consists of lepromatous bacilli packed within mononuclear cells or acid-fast material with accompanying foreign body reaction. Inside the eye, leprosy bacilli preferentially lodge in the iris and ciliary body, due to the relatively cooler temperatures and high vascularity.

questions.text: A patient presents with areas of yellowish papular skin lesions and redundant and inelastic folds of skin on the neck and thighs. Which of the following ocular findings is not seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given case suggests a diagnosis of pseudoxanthoma elasticum. Arterial macroaneurysm is not a feature of this disease.

Ocular findings in pseudoxanthoma elasticum:

  • Blue sclera
  • Angioid streaks
  • Optic nerve head drusen
  • “Peau-d’orange” appearance of the retina
  • Choroidal neovascularization

questions.text: An elderly patient admitted with multiple comorbidities in the ICU, developed exposure keratitis and ulceration. An ophthalmology opinion was sought. Incidentally, on fundoscopy, the resident found the following picture. What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous haemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.

questions.text: In patients with a long-standing history of Crohn's disease, which of the following ocular complications is the most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The most common ocular manifestation of Crohn’s disease is episcleritis.

Uveitis is associated with both Ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A patient with a history of decreased vision was evaluated with fundus fluorescein angiography. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Dye can be seen leaking through abnormal neovascular fronds. Both neovascularization of the disc (NVD), as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE i.e., 2 DD away from the optic disc margin), are seen.

The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.
